qas.question: When did Cook's ships cross the Antarctic circle?
What kept Captain Cook from getting too close to Antarctica?
How many men sighted Antarctica in 1820?
How close did von Bellingshausen and Lazarev come to Antarctica?
When was the first recorded landing on Antarctica?
Who's ship crossed the Antarctic Circle in the 17th century?
What ships did Cook use to circle the Antarctic Circle?

plausible_answers.text: von Bellingshausen (a captain in the Imperial Russian Navy), Edward Bransfield (a captain in the Royal Navy), and Nathaniel Palmer

qas.question: Who sighted Antarctica or its ice shelf in the 18th century?
What ships were captained by Bransfield and Lazarev?
Who sighted land ten months before Bransfield?
What ships crossed the Arctic Circle on 17 January 1773?
What crossed the Antarctic Circle in December 1774?
Who came within 120 mi of the Antarctic coast in 1773?
What did three might sight in 1802?
What ice shelf was spotted within 32 mi from Queen Maud's Land?

context: European maps continued to show this hypothesized land until <b5_0>Captain James Cook<b5_0/>'s ships, <b6_0><b10_0><b11_0>HMS Resolution and Adventure<b11_0/><b10_0/><b6_0/>, crossed the Antarctic Circle on <a0_0>17 January 1773<a0_0/>, in December 1773 and again in January 1774. <b12_0>Cook<b12_0/> came within about 120 km (75 mi) of the Antarctic coast before retreating in the face of <a1_0>field ice<a1_0/> in January 1773. The first confirmed sighting of Antarctica can be narrowed down to the crews of ships captained by three individuals. According to various organizations (the National Science Foundation, NASA, the University of California, San Diego, and other sources), ships captained by <a2_0>three<a2_0/> men sighted <b13_0>Antarctica or its ice shelf<b13_0/> in 1820: <b7_0>von Bellingshausen (a captain in the Imperial Russian Navy), Edward Bransfield (a captain in the Royal Navy), and Nathaniel Palmer<b7_0/> (a sealer out of Stonington, Connecticut). The expedition led by von Bellingshausen and Lazarev on the ships <b8_0>Vostok and Mirny<b8_0/> reached a point within <a3_0>32 km<a3_0/> (20 mi) from Queen Maud's Land and recorded the sight of an ice shelf at 69°21′28″S 2°14′50″W﻿ / ﻿69.35778°S 2.24722°W﻿ / -69.35778; -2.24722, which became known as the <b14_0>Fimbul ice shelf<b14_0/>. This happened three days before Bransfield sighted land, and ten months before <b9_0>Palmer<b9_0/> did so in November 1820. The first documented landing on Antarctica was by the American sealer John Davis, apparently at Hughes Bay, near Cape Charles, in West Antarctica on 7 February 1821, although some historians dispute this claim. The first recorded and confirmed landing was at Cape Adair in <a4_0>1895<a4_0/>.
